p: The dengue viruses (DENV) are the most important arboviral pathogens of humans causing an estimated 390 million infections annually, of which approximately one quarter are symptomatic [ 1]. Infection with DENV causes a spectrum of clinical outcomes ranging from self-limiting febrile illness (dengue fever, DF) to potentially fatal severe dengue, characterized by plasma leakage, thrombocytopenia, and hypovolemic shock. Dengue is endemic in more than 100 tropical and subtropical countries, where the principal mosquito vectors Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus are found [ 2, 3].
